Il 29 aprile Berkshire Hathaway, guidata dal famoso investitore Warren E. Buffett, ha acquistato un totale di 311.637 azioni della Serie C Liberty SiriusXM Common Stock di Liberty Media a un prezzo medio di 25,4664 dollari, pari a un investimento sostanziale di circa 7,94 milioni di dollari.\n\nLa transazione \u00e8 stata resa ", "tur": "Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) Inc. \u015firketindeki \u00f6nemli yat\u0131r\u0131m\u0131n\u0131 \u00f6nemli \u00f6l\u00e7\u00fcde azalt\u0131rken, nakit rezervleri 189 milyar $ gibi rekor bir seviyeye y\u00fckseldi. Warren Buffett liderli\u011findeki holding ayr\u0131ca, sigorta faaliyetlerinin performans\u0131 ve y\u00fckselen faiz oranlar\u0131 nedeniyle yat\u0131r\u0131mlardan elde edilen y\u00fcksek gelirle 11 milyar dolar\u0131 a\u015fan rekor bir faaliyet kar\u0131 bildirdi.\n\nBerkshire'\u0131n Apple'daki hisselerinin de\u011feri bir \u00f6nceki y\u0131l\u0131n sonunda 174,3 milyar dolar"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Omaha, Nebraska"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 92}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Opportunities/Opposing_Views", "label": "dmoz/Business/Opportunities/Opposing Views", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Personal_Finance/Investing", "label": "dmoz/Home/Personal Finance/Investing", "wgt": 93}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 85}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 300, "zho": 206, "deu": 60, "por": 40, "spa": 36, "fra": 20, "rus": 18, "ita": 14, "tur": 8}, "sentiment": 0.1764705882352942}
{"uri": "8112219182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:47:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:47:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:47:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/business/economy/buffett-lauds-apple-despite-stake-cut-confident-in-berkshires-future", "title": "Buffett lauds Apple despite stake cut, confident in Berkshire's future", "body": "Warren Buffett set in a confident tone, assuring Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives that will succeed him are ready for the role, and praised Apple, although Berkshire reduced its stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nAt Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who, since 1965, transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain had proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, to have the final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks upon becoming chief executive.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99.\n\nBuffett described Munger, his longtime friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign that he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking that he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise move, Berkshire reported selling about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924, when he was born, and clips of Buffett and Munger over the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective on Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8112178661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:12:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:12:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T10:08:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.westhawaiitoday.com/2024/05/05/nation-world-news/buffett-says-berkshire-in-good-hands-lauds-apple-despite-lowering-stake/", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire in good hands, lauds Apple despite lowering stake - West Hawaii Today", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska -- Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nDecreasing Apple stake, growing cash\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard &Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nLines formed hours before meeting\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "westhawaiitoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "West Hawaii Today"}, "authors": [{"uri": "none@westhawaiitoday.com", "name": {"uri": "8111648198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:55:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:55:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:54:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/05/04/breaking-news/warren-buffett-says-berkshire-is-in-good-hands-lauds-apple/", "title": "Warren Buffett says Berkshire is in good hands, lauds Apple | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Berkshire Hathaway Chairman Warren Buffett attends the Berkshire Hathaway Inc annual shareholders' meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, Friday\n\nOMAHA, Neb. >> Warren Buffett assured shareholders today that the executives expected to succeed him at Berkshire Hathaway were ready for the job and he heaped praise on Apple even though Berkshire recently trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor also paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, which reached a record $189 billion last quarter, to continue growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who took over Berkshire in 1965 and turned it into an expansive company valued at $862 billion owning BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and other businesses. It was also the first since Munger, Buffett's longtime friend and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\nIn a downtown Omaha arena, Buffett, 93, was joined on stage by Vice Chairmen Greg Abel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Ajit Jain.\n\nAbel, 61, and Jain, 72 have had direct oversight of Berkshire's dozens of operating subsidiaries since 2018, freeing Buffett and, before his death, Munger to focus on capital allocation. Buffett said he was happy with that arrangement.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nWhen Abel eventually becomes CEO, Buffett said he would want him to have final say on decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\n\"He understands businesses extremely well, and if you understand businesses you understand common stocks,\" Buffett said.\n\nInvestors have long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise move, the conglomerate also reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main cause for Berkshire's cash hoard to soar. Buffett said cash might grow from $189 billion last quarter to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite decreasing Berkshire's stake in Apple, Buffett praised the tech company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple represented too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain the company's biggest investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nBuffett added that he expects the U.S. government to increase taxes to tackle a widening fiscal deficit rather than reduce spending.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020, but called them a substantial challenge.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nHe was the \"architect of today's Berkshire,\" Buffett said.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up early outside the arena in raw, rainy weather. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe shareholder weekend, which Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this,\" Lam said.\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about life and wealth.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said at the end of toay's question and answer session. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8111894655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "05:17:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T05:17:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T05:17:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.asiaone.com/money/buffett-lauds-apple-despite-trimming-stake-says-berkshire-good-hands", "title": "AsiaOne", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska -- Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday (May 4) that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record US$189 billion (S$255 billion), to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an US$862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's US$335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39 per cent jump in operating profit to a record US$11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13 per cent of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to US$135.4 billion from US$174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11 per cent in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to US$200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23 per cent over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25 per cent gain, Berkshire has risen 218 per cent over the last decade versus the S&P's 172 per cent gain.\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 am, many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who travelled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2.30 am.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "asiaone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "https://www.chinadailyhk.com/upload/main/image/2024/05/05/d3b6d8a47317da5dca60bbbe3238c2e5.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9538966", "eventUri": "eng-9538966", "location": {"type": {"uri": "8113467993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:05:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:05:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T09:04:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.investing.com/news/world-news/buffett-says-berkshire-in-good-hands-lauds-apple-despite-lowering-stake-3420052", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire in good hands, lauds Apple despite lowering stake By Reuters", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRKa) shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares (NASDAQ:AAPL), reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express (NYSE:AXP) and Coca-Cola (NYSE:KO).\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nLINES FORMED HOURS BEFORE MEETING\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "investing.com", "dataType": "news", "title": hands, lauds Apple despite lowering stake", "body": "The legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing\n\nWarren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nLINES FORMED HOURS BEFORE MEETING\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel in Omaha; additional reporting by Scott Morgan in Omaha and Davide Barbuscia in New York; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)", "source": {"uri": "zawya.com", {"uri": "8112459997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "14:40:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T14:40:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:40:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/2024-05-05-warren-buffett-assures-berkshire-shareholders-over-successors/", "title": "Warren Buffett assures Berkshire shareholders over successors", "body": "Omaha -- Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple though Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nThe legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189bn, to keep growing.\n\nBerkshire's annual meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862bn colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that vice-chairs Greg Abel and Ajit Jain had proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as CEO in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got someone like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how [Abel] does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, upon becoming CEO, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9bn equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists\", was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire\".\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nApple shares\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2bn.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4bn from $174.3bn. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200bn this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time\", Buffett said with Apple CEO Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollar from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nLaconic comebacks\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the past decade vs the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7am, many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who travelled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2.30am.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew more than 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "businesslive.co.za", "dataType": "news", "title": Our special coverage will begin Saturday at 9:30 a.m. ET.\n\nJazwares, the American toymaker best known for its Squishmallows plushie line, was a hit last year when it first displayed its wares at Berkshire Hathaway's conference, including the debut of a Warren Buffett plushie. This year, the company expanded its exhibit in the convention hall, making it three times larger.\n\nSome highlights include the latest Squishmallows toys for Buffett and Charlie Munger, a splashy Squishmallows pit, as well as other displays.\n\nThe Bookworm only had one book to sell this year: \"Poor Charlie's Almanack: The Essential Wit and Wisdom of Charles T. Munger.\" That was at the request of Buffett in honor of his business partner of more than 60 years, who passed away in November at the age of 99.\n\nBerkshire acquired pilot training company FlightSafety in 1996. At Friday's shopping event, the firm brought a taste of what its training program looks like for professional pilots. Shareholders lined up to put on virtual reality glasses and experience the flight simulation training.\n\nTruck-stop giant Pilot Travel Centers put up a big display with a real-sized red truck. The firm is largest operator of travel centers in North America, with more than 750 locations. Berkshire now fully owns Pilot Travel after buying the remaining 20% ownership interest from the Haslam family. The deal was not without drama as the Haslams last year sued Berkshire in a complaint that accused the conglomerate of using so-called pushdown accounting without authorization from the family.\n\nIn 2016, Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway bought Duracell from Procter & Gamble, offering the consumer giant $4.7 billion of the shares it owned in P&G in exchange for the battery maker.\n\nBrooks Running attracted a long line of shareholders snapping up the 2024 special edition of its running shoes with \"brk\" on the side and a cartoon of a running Buffett on the insoles. Many shareholders are also set to participate in the Brooks \"Invest in Yourself\" 5K fun run and walk on Sunday, the morning following the annual meeting.\n\nWarren Buffett bought Dairy Queen in 1998 in a roughly $600 million transaction, and has made trips to the Omaha locations with his great-grandchildren. {"uri": "8112385147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:27:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:27:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:26:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.dtnext.in/news/business/buffett-lauds-apple-despite-trimming-stake-says-berkshire-is-in-good-hands-783206", "title": "Buffett lauds Apple despite trimming stake, says Berkshire is in good hands", "body": "OMAHA: Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway (BRKa.N), opens new tab shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple (AAPL.O), opens new tab although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express (AXP.N), opens new tab and Coca-Cola (KO.N)\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience. Berkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's (.SPX), opens new tab 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nLINES FORMED HOURS BEFORE MEETING\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "dtnext.in", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-345481894", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "10:04:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T10:04:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:46:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.zeebiz.com/markets/global-markets/news-buffett-lauds-apple-despite-trimming-stake-says-berkshire-is-in-good-hands-288140", "title": "Warren Buffett lauds Apple despite trimming stake, says Berkshire is in good hands", "body": "Buffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks, Representational image. Source: Reuters\n\nWarren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39 per cent jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.In a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13 per cent of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11 per cent in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born, and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street, and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23 per cent over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25 per cent gain, Berkshire has risen 218 per cent over the last decade versus the S&P's 172 per cent gain.\n\nLINES FORMED HOURS BEFORE MEETING\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "zeebiz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Zee {"uri": "8111691251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "00:21:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T00:21:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T00:06:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/buffett-says-berkshire-in-good-hands,-lauds-apple-despite-lowering-stake/76903413", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire in good hands, lauds Apple despite lowering stake", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nLINES FORMED HOURS BEFORE MEETING\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel in Omaha; additional {"uri": "8113732409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "11:56:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T11:56:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T11:56:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.carriermanagement.com/news/2024/05/06/261830.htm", "title": "Buffett Praises Successors, Lauds Apple Despite Lowering Stake - Carrier Management", "body": "Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, GEICO car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nDecreasing Apple Stake, Growing Cash\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39 percent jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13 percent of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11 percent in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23 percent over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's .SPX 25 percent gain, Berkshire has risen 218 percent over the last decade versus the S&P's 172 percent gain.\n\nLines Form Hours Before Meeting\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel in Omaha; additional reporting by Scott Morgan in Omaha and Davide Barbuscia in New York; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)\n\nFeatured Photo:", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8111572310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:05:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:05:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:04:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/buffett-says-berkshire-is-in-good-hands,-lauds-apple-despite-trimming-stake/76903413", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire is in good hands, lauds Apple despite trimming stake", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett assured shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him at Berkshire Hathaway were ready for the job and heaped praise on Apple even though Berkshire recently trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting, the legendary investor also paid tribute to his late partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, which reached a record $189 billion last quarter, to continue growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who took over Berkshire in 1965 and turned it into an expansive company valued at $862 billion and owning BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and other businesses. It was also the first since Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\nIn a downtown Omaha arena, Buffett was joined on stage by Vice Chairmen Greg Abel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Ajit Jain.\n\nAbel, 61, and Jain, 72 have had direct oversight of Berkshire's dozens of operating subsidiaries since 2018, freeing Buffett and, before his death, Munger to focus on capital allocation. Buffett said he was happy with that arrangement.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nBuffett, 93, gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nIn a surprise move, the conglomerate also reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main cause for Berkshire's cash hoard to soar. Buffett said cash might grow from $189 billion last quarter to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite decreasing Berkshire's stake in Apple, Buffett praised the tech company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple represented too much of Berkshire's now $335.9 billion equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain the company's biggest investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nBuffett added that he expects the U.S. government to increase taxes to tackle a widening fiscal deficit rather than reduce spending.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020, but called them a substantial challenge.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including photos of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nHe was the \"architect of today's Berkshire,\" Buffett said.\n\nEARLY WAKE-UP\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up early outside the arena in raw, rainy weather. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, said he arrived at 1:41 a.m. to get in line, with a lawn chair to sit and sleep on.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire,\" he said. \"They're so diversified and have a good company culture.\"\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nThe shareholder weekend, which Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment manager who along with 40 others flew from Hong Kong. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "swi_swissinfo_ch@swissinfo.ch", "name": "Swi {"uri": "8111477282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "19:05:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T19:05:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T19:04:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/buffett-reassures-about-berkshire's-future,-praises-apple-even-as-he-sells-it/76903413", "title": "Buffett reassures about Berkshire's future, praises Apple even as he sells it", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) - Warren Buffett paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, while reassuring shareholders that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job.\n\nBuffett, legendary for his investing acumen, also praised Apple after unexpectedly revealing that Berkshire had reduced its stake in the iPhone maker. He said the company was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who took over Berkshire in 1965 and turned it into an expansive company valued at a $862 billion owning BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and other businesses. Saturday's meeting was the first since Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\nBuffett, 93, signaled no plans to step aside himself, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nEarly in the meeting, shareholders watched a video paying to tribute to Munger, including photos of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and video of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was the \"architect of today's Berkshire,\" Buffett said. \"The architect is the person who dreams of and designs, and finally supervises the construction of great structures. The carpenters and the beavers -- that's me -- are needed, but the architect is the genius of Berkshire.\"\n\nIn a downtown Omaha arena, Buffett was joined on stage by Vice Chairmen Greg Abel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Ajit Jain.\n\nAbel, 61, and Jain, 72 have had direct oversight of Berkshire's dozens of operating subsidiaries since 2018, freeing Buffett and, before his death, Munger to focus on capital allocation. Buffett said he was happy with that arrangement.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nPrior to the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nBut in a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main cause for Berkshire's cash hoard to soar to $189 billion, also a record. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nBut some investors expressed concern that Apple represented too much of Berkshire's now $335.9 billion equity portfolio.\n\nStill, with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience, Buffett told Berkshire shareholders: \"Unless something dramatic happens that really changes capital allocation, we will have Apple as our largest investment.\"\n\nAnd he said Berkshire remains committed to investing in the United States. \"If we do something really big it's extremely likely it will be in the United States,\" he said.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020, but called them a substantial challenge.\n\nEARLY WAKE-UP\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up early outside the arena in raw, rainy weather. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment manager who along with 40 others flew from Hong Kong. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, said he arrived at 1:41 a.m. to get in line, with a lawn chair to sit and sleep on.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire,\" he said. \"They're so diversified and have a good company culture.\"\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nThe shareholder weekend, which Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A Buffett, admirer, she became a Berkshire shareholder 15 years ago.\n\n\"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri":
