{"uri": "8111524648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "20:03:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T20:03:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T20:02:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/buffett-reassures-about-berkshires-future-praises-apple-even-as-he-sells-it/article_eb6d27a5-ce71-5dca-86c4-15a29bcc0861.html", "title": "Buffett reassures about Berkshire's future, praises Apple even as he sells it", "body": "A cutout picture of Berkshire Hathaway Chairman Warren Buffett welcomes shareholders to shop at the Pampered Chef booth at the Berkshire Hathaway Inc annual shareholders' meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, U.S. May 3, 2024. REUTERS/Scott Morgan\n\nBy Jonathan Stempel and Koh Gui Qing\n\nOMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) - Warren Buffett paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, while reassuring shareholders that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job.\n\nBuffett, legendary for his investing acumen, also praised Apple after unexpectedly revealing that Berkshire had reduced its stake in the iPhone maker. He said the company was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who took over Berkshire in 1965 and turned it into an expansive company valued at a $862 billion owning BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and other businesses. Saturday's meeting was the first since Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\nBuffett, 93, signaled no plans to step aside himself, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nEarly in the meeting, shareholders watched a video paying to tribute to Munger, including photos of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and video of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was the \"architect of today's Berkshire,\" Buffett said. \"The architect is the person who dreams of and designs, and finally supervises the construction of great structures. The carpenters and the beavers -- that's me -- are needed, but the architect is the genius of Berkshire.\"\n\nIn a downtown Omaha arena, Buffett was joined on stage by Vice Chairmen Greg Abel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Ajit Jain.\n\nAbel, 61, and Jain, 72 have had direct oversight of Berkshire's dozens of operating subsidiaries since 2018, freeing Buffett and, before his death, Munger to focus on capital allocation. Buffett said he was happy with that arrangement.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nPrior to the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nBut in a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main cause for Berkshire's cash hoard to soar to $189 billion, also a record. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nBut some investors expressed concern that Apple represented too much of Berkshire's now $335.9 billion equity portfolio.\n\nStill, with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience, Buffett told Berkshire shareholders: \"Unless something dramatic happens that really changes capital allocation, we will have Apple as our largest investment.\"\n\nAnd he said Berkshire remains committed to investing in the United States. \"If we do something really big it's extremely likely it will be in the United States,\" he said.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020, but called them a substantial challenge.\n\nEARLY WAKE-UP\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up early outside the arena in raw, rainy weather. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment manager who along with 40 others flew from Hong Kong. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, said he arrived at 1:41 a.m. to get in line, with a lawn chair to sit and sleep on.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire,\" he said. \"They're so diversified and have a good company culture.\"\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nThe shareholder weekend, which Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A Buffett, admirer, she became a Berkshire shareholder 15 years ago.\n\n\"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8111681538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:50:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:50:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:50:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/buffett-says-berkshire-in-good-hands-lauds-apple-despite-lowering-stake/article_eb6d27a5-ce71-5dca-86c4-15a29bcc0861.html", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire in good hands, lauds Apple despite lowering stake", "body": "By Jonathan Stempel and Koh Gui Qing\n\nOMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett assured Berkshire Hathaway shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him were ready for the job, and he heaped praise on Apple although Berkshire trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire's annual meeting, the legendary investor paid tribute to his late business partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, now a record $189 billion, to keep growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who since 1965 transformed Berkshire from a failing textile company into an $862 billion colossus owning the BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and dozens of other businesses.\n\nBuffett, 93, told shareholders that Vice Chairmen Greg Abel and Ajit Jain have proven themselves the right people to lead Berkshire after he departs.\n\nAbel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Jain have directly overseen Berkshire's operating subsidiaries since 2018.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" Buffett said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\n\"I don't know quite how (Abel) does it, but we've got the right person, I can tell you that,\" he added.\n\nBuffett said he would want Abel, 61, upon becoming chief executive, to have final say on capital allocation decisions regarding Berkshire's portfolio of public stocks.\n\nInvestors had long considered Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, who manage part of Berkshire's $335.9 billion equity portfolio, leading candidates to manage more or all of it.\n\nThe meeting, part of a weekend Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" was the first since Munger died in November at age 99. Buffett described Munger, his longtime his friend and foil, as the \"architect of today's Berkshire.\"\n\nBuffett gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nIn a surprise, Berkshire reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main reason Berkshire's cash hoard soared. Buffett said cash might grow to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks he sees from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite reducing the Apple stake, Buffett praised the company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest and largest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple comprised too much of Berkshire's equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain his company's biggest stock investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020. He described it as a substantial challenge, and said many claims were unfounded.\n\nShareholders reelected all 14 Berkshire directors, and rejected six shareholder proposals, all of which Buffett opposed.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including scenes of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nLINES FORMED HOURS BEFORE MEETING\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up in raw, rainy weather to enter the arena, sometimes several hours in advance. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nThe weekend also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nSerena Lam, 32, an investment manager who traveled with 40 others from Hong Kong, said she arrived at 2:30 a.m.\n\n\"I want to see Warren Buffett,\" she said. \"I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAs usual, Buffett interspersed comments on Berkshire's portfolio with musings about wealth and life, including his own.\n\n\"I enjoy managing money for the people who trust me. I like the feeling of being trusted,\" he said. \"If I'm lucky, I can go on for six or seven years, or it might end tomorrow.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel in Omaha; additional reporting by Scott Morgan in Omaha and Davide Barbuscia in New York; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8111541873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "20:25:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T20:25:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T20:24:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/berkshire-hathaway-agm-warren-buffet-outlines-roles-of-successors-pays-tribute-to-charlie-munger-11714844055626.html", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire is in good hands, lauds Apple despite trimming stake", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska, May 4 (Reuters) - Warren Buffett assured shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him at Berkshire Hathaway were ready for the job and heaped praise on Apple even though Berkshire recently trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting, the legendary investor also paid tribute to his late partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, which reached a record $189 billion last quarter, to continue growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who took over Berkshire in 1965 and turned it into an expansive company valued at $862 billion and owning BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and other businesses. It was also the first since Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\nIn a downtown Omaha arena, Buffett was joined on stage by Vice Chairmen Greg Abel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Ajit Jain.\n\nAbel, 61, and Jain, 72 have had direct oversight of Berkshire's dozens of operating subsidiaries since 2018, freeing Buffett and, before his death, Munger to focus on capital allocation. Buffett said he was happy with that arrangement.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nBuffett, 93, gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nIn a surprise move, the conglomerate also reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main cause for Berkshire's cash hoard to soar. Buffett said cash might grow from $189 billion last quarter to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite decreasing Berkshire's stake in Apple, Buffett praised the tech company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple represented too much of Berkshire's now $335.9 billion equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain the company's biggest investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nBuffett added that he expects the U.S. government to increase taxes to tackle a widening fiscal deficit rather than reduce spending.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020, but called them a substantial challenge.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including photos of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nHe was the \"architect of today's Berkshire,\" Buffett said.\n\nEARLY WAKE-UP\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up early outside the arena in raw, rainy weather. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, said he arrived at 1:41 a.m. to get in line, with a lawn chair to sit and sleep on.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire,\" he said. \"They're so diversified and have a good company culture.\"\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nThe shareholder weekend, which Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment manager who along with 40 others flew from Hong Kong. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\" (Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)\n\nMilestone Alert! "https://images.livemint.com/img/2018/12/28/600x338/News_-_world_1545994908237.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9538966", "eventUri": "eng-9538966", "location": {"type": "place", {"uri": "8111383457", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "17:19:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T17:19:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T17:19:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/at-berkshire-shareholder-meeting-buffett-exhorts-successors-pays-tribute-to-munger/article_eb6d27a5-ce71-5dca-86c4-15a29bcc0861.html", "title": "At Berkshire shareholder meeting, Buffett exhorts successors, pays tribute to Munger", "body": "A cutout picture of Berkshire Hathaway Chairman Warren Buffett welcomes shareholders to shop at the Pampered Chef booth at the Berkshire Hathaway Inc annual shareholders' meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, U.S. May 3, 2024. REUTERS/Scott Morgan\n\nBy Jonathan Stempel and Koh Gui Qing\n\nOMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett took the stage at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, paying tribute to his longtime business partner Charlie Munger while outlining the expanded roles of the executives who are designated to eventually succeed him in leading the company.\n\nThe meeting is the 60th for Buffett, 93, since he took over Berkshire in 1965. He has largely stopped appearing publicly to discuss the company. He told investors in November that he felt good but knew he was \"playing in extra innings.\"\n\nBuffett said he was comfortable letting chief executives of Berkshire's operating units deal directly with Vice Chairman Greg Abel and Vice Chairman Ajit Jain. Abel, 61, designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, sat on stage with Buffett.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nThe shareholder meeting is the first since Charlie Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\n\"I have been in the position of having people I trust around me,\" said Buffett on stage, who then referenced Munger. Earlier, in a video ahead of the meeting, Berkshire played a tribute to Munger showing photos of Omaha from 1924 and footage of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\n\"Charlie's architectural thoughts led to the Berkshire Hathaway of today,\" said Buffett on the video. His design, he said, \"lives beyond his lifetime and will live far beyond mine.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter earnings that showed that its cash pile swelled to $189 billion as of March 31 while the size of its stake in Apple fell. Based on changes in Apple's stock price, Berkshire appeared to have sold 13% of its Apple shares in the quarter.\n\nBuffett has long touted the iPhone maker's leadership and market dominance. Some investors have expressed concern that Apple had become too large a part of Berkshire's investment portfolio. Apple CEO Tim Cook was in the audience at the meeting on Saturday.\n\nStill, Buffett assured shareholders that \"unless something dramatic happens that really changes capital allocation, we will have Apple as our largest investment.\"\n\nBuffett also said he didn't mind expanding the company's cash stake, with comparatively few alternatives in the equity markets and conflicts around the world, and said cash could top $200 billion by the end of June.\n\nHe added that Berkshire remains committed to the U.S.\n\n\"We will be American oriented,\" Buffett said. \"If we do something really big it's extremely likely it will be in the United States.\"\n\nBuffett assured shareholders that \"unless something dramatic happens\" that really changes Berkshire's capital allocation, it will have Apple as its largest investment.\n\nAbel addressed issues at Berkshire's energy business, saying Berkshire will fight litigation related to wildfires but that it was a substantial challenge. The unit faces billions of dollars in claims against its PacifiCorp unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020.\n\nIn downtown Omaha, hundreds of shareholders waited in line overnight to get in early. When the doors opened, some shareholders ran in to get good seats and the auditorium quickly filled up.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30 a.m.,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment portfolio manager who flew in with 40 others from Hong Kong and was standing first in line at one of the entrances. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, brought a lawn chair to sit in while on line.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire. They're so diversified and have a good company culture. That's the one thing that I loved.\"\n\nInvestors are focused on how the conglomerate will evolve as it faces challenges including how best to grow without overpaying for acquisitions, whether to pay a dividend and how to deploy cash on hand that stood at $189 billion as of the end of March.\n\nSUCCESSION TOP OF MIND Berkshire is a $862 billion conglomerate with dozens of businesses including BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and Fruit of the Loom. It also owns well over $300 billion of stocks, close to half of which is Apple.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year, lagging the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain. Over the last decade, it has risen 218% versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBuffett is expected to face a wide array of questions on Saturday from major investments such as Apple and Occidental Petroleum to how elevated interest rates have affected the company. Berkshire will also release first-quarter results and shareholders will vote on six proposals about climate, diversity and China. Buffett opposes all six. The weekend features opportunities for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits featuring Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A 15-year shareholder, Gearhart said she was mainly concerned with what Buffett might say regarding his succession. \"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8111408477", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "17:46:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T17:46:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T17:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/companies/news/berkshire-hathaway-agm-warren-buffet-outlines-roles-of-successors-pays-tribute-to-charlie-munger-11714844055626.html", "title": "Berkshire Hathaway AGM: Warren Buffet outlines roles of successors, pays tribute to Charlie Munger", "body": "Warren Buffett took the stage at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, paying tribute to his longtime business partner Charlie Munger while outlining the expanded roles of the executives who are designated to eventually succeed him in leading the company.\n\nThe meeting is the 60th for Buffett, 93, since he took over Berkshire in 1965. He has largely stopped appearing publicly to discuss the company. He told investors in November that he felt good but knew he was \"playing in extra innings.\"\n\nBuffett said he was comfortable letting chief executives of Berkshire's operating units deal directly with Vice Chairman Greg Abel and Vice Chairman Ajit Jain. Abel, 61, designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, sat on stage with Buffett.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\" The shareholder meeting is the first since Charlie Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\n\"I have been in the position of having people I trust around me,\" said Buffett on stage, who then referenced Munger. Earlier, in a video ahead of the meeting, Berkshire played a tribute to Munger showing photos of Omaha from 1924 and footage of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\n\"Charlie's architectural thoughts led to the Berkshire Hathaway of today,\" said Buffett on the video. His design, he said, \"lives beyond his lifetime and will live far beyond mine.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter earnings that showed that its cash pile swelled to $189 billion as of March 31 while the size of its stake in Apple fell. Based on changes in Apple's stock price, Berkshire appeared to have sold 13% of its Apple shares in the quarter.\n\nBuffett has long touted the iPhone maker's leadership and market dominance. Some investors have expressed concern that Apple had become too large a part of Berkshire's investment portfolio. Apple CEO Tim Cook was in the audience at the meeting on Saturday.\n\nStill, Buffett assured shareholders that \"unless something dramatic happens that really changes capital allocation, we will have Apple as our largest investment.\"\n\nBuffett also said he didn't mind expanding the company's cash stake, with comparatively few alternatives in the equity markets and conflicts around the world, and said cash could top $200 billion by the end of June.\n\nHe added that Berkshire remains committed to the U.S.\n\n\"We will be American oriented,\" Buffett said. \"If we do something really big it's extremely likely it will be in the United States.\"\n\nBuffett assured shareholders that \"unless something dramatic happens\" that really changes Berkshire's capital allocation, it will have Apple as its largest investment.\n\nAbel addressed issues at Berkshire's energy business, saying Berkshire will fight litigation related to wildfires but that it was a substantial challenge. The unit faces billions of dollars in claims against its PacifiCorp unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020.\n\nIn downtown Omaha, hundreds of shareholders waited in line overnight to get in early. When the doors opened, some shareholders ran in to get good seats and the auditorium quickly filled up.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30 a.m.,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment portfolio manager who flew in with 40 others from Hong Kong and was standing first in line at one of the entrances. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, brought a lawn chair to sit in while on line.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire. They're so diversified and have a good company culture. That's the one thing that I loved.\"\n\nInvestors are focused on how the conglomerate will evolve as it faces challenges including how best to grow without overpaying for acquisitions, whether to pay a dividend and how to deploy cash on hand that stood at $189 billion as of the end of March.\n\nSUCCESSION TOP OF MIND\n\nBerkshire is a $862 billion conglomerate with dozens of businesses including BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and Fruit of the Loom. It also owns well over $300 billion of stocks, close to half of which is Apple.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year, lagging the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain. Over the last decade, it has risen 218% versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBuffett is expected to face a wide array of questions on Saturday from major investments such as Apple and Occidental Petroleum to how elevated interest rates have affected the company.\n\nBerkshire will also release first-quarter results and shareholders will vote on six proposals about climate, diversity and China. Buffett opposes all six.\n\nThe weekend features opportunities for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits featuring Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A 15-year shareholder, Gearhart said she was mainly concerned with what Buffett might say regarding his succession.\n\n\"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"\n\nMilestone Alert! "https://www.livemint.com/lm-img/img/2024/05/04/600x338/2-0-121336214-warren-buffet-4c-0_1681895047181_1714844282118.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9538966", "eventUri": {"uri": "2024-05-345205129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "20:26:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T20:26:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T10:05:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/buffett-says-berkshire-is-in-good-hands-lauds-apple-despite-trimming-stake/article_eb6d27a5-ce71-5dca-86c4-15a29bcc0861.html", "title": "Buffett says Berkshire is in good hands, lauds Apple despite trimming stake", "body": "By Jonathan Stempel and Koh Gui Qing\n\nOMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett assured shareholders on Saturday that the executives expected to succeed him at Berkshire Hathaway were ready for the job and heaped praise on Apple even though Berkshire recently trimmed its position in the iPhone maker.\n\nSpeaking at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting, the legendary investor also paid tribute to his late partner Charlie Munger and said he expected the conglomerate's cash pile, which reached a record $189 billion last quarter, to continue growing.\n\nThe meeting was the 60th for Buffett, who took over Berkshire in 1965 and turned it into an expansive company valued at $862 billion and owning BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and other businesses. It was also the first since Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\nIn a downtown Omaha arena, Buffett was joined on stage by Vice Chairmen Greg Abel, who was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, and Ajit Jain.\n\nAbel, 61, and Jain, 72 have had direct oversight of Berkshire's dozens of operating subsidiaries since 2018, freeing Buffett and, before his death, Munger to focus on capital allocation. Buffett said he was happy with that arrangement.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nBuffett, 93, gave no sign he plans to step aside, telling shareholders, \"I feel fine,\" while joking he shouldn't take on four-year employment contracts.\n\nBefore the meeting, Berkshire announced first-quarter results, including a 39% jump in operating profit to a record $11.2 billion.\n\nDECREASING APPLE STAKE, GROWING CASH\n\nIn a surprise move, the conglomerate also reported it had sold about 13% of its Apple shares, reducing the value of its stake to $135.4 billion from $174.3 billion. Apple's stock price fell 11% in the quarter.\n\nThe sale was the main cause for Berkshire's cash hoard to soar. Buffett said cash might grow from $189 billion last quarter to $200 billion this quarter, reflecting the risks from high stock market valuations and geopolitical conflicts.\n\nDespite decreasing Berkshire's stake in Apple, Buffett praised the tech company, saying it was \"an even better business\" than two of Berkshire's oldest investments, American Express and Coca-Cola.\n\nThe iPhone was \"one of the greatest products, and it may be the greatest product, of all time,\" Buffett said with Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook in the audience.\n\nBerkshire invested in Apple in 2016, and the normally tech-phobic Buffett came to view it as a consumer goods company with strong pricing power and devoted customers.\n\nWhile some investors have expressed concern that Apple represented too much of Berkshire's now $335.9 billion equity portfolio, Buffett said Apple would remain the company's biggest investment, barring unforeseen events.\n\nBuffett added that he expects the U.S. government to increase taxes to tackle a widening fiscal deficit rather than reduce spending.\n\nAbel, meanwhile, pledged to fight lawsuits seeking tens of billions of dollars from Berkshire's PacifiCorp utility unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020, but called them a substantial challenge.\n\nAt the start of the meeting, shareholders watched a video tribute to Munger, including photos of Omaha from 1924 when he was born and clips of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger had been a fixture on stage with Buffett at the meetings, known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's musings about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\nHe was the \"architect of today's Berkshire,\" Buffett said.\n\nEARLY WAKE-UP\n\nBefore the meeting, thousands lined up early outside the arena in raw, rainy weather. When the doors opened at 7 a.m., many ran for the best seats.\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, said he arrived at 1:41 a.m. to get in line, with a lawn chair to sit and sleep on.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire,\" he said. \"They're so diversified and have a good company culture.\"\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year. While that lags the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain, Berkshire has risen 218% over the last decade versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nThe shareholder weekend, which Buffett calls \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" also featured an exhibit hall for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits by Berkshire-owned companies.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment manager who along with 40 others flew from Hong Kong. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update\n\nYour morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters.\n\nSuccess! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter.\n\nView all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8111264931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "15:21:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T15:21:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T15:20:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/warren-buffett-takes-stage-at-berkshire-meeting-pays-tribute-to-munger-cuts-apple-stake/articleshow/109843850.cms", "title": "Warren Buffett takes stage at Berkshire meeting, pays tribute to Munger, cuts Apple stake", "body": "At Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting, Warren Buffett celebrated Charlie Munger, discussed growing earnings, and addressed the $189 billion cash pile. Shareholders eagerly awaited insights on Berkshire's future direction and succession plan.Warren Buffett took the stage at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, paying tribute to his longtime business partner Charlie Munger who died last year and outlining Berkshire's goal to grow earnings.\n\nThe meeting is the 60th for Buffett, 93, since he took over Berkshire in 1965. He has largely stopped appearing publicly to discuss the company. He told investors in November that he felt good but knew he was \"playing in extra innings.\"\n\nThe shareholder meeting is the first since Charlie Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99. In a video ahead of the meeting, Berkshire played a tribute to Charlie Munger showing photos of Omaha from 1924 and footage of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\n\"Charlie's architectural thoughts led to the Berkshire Hathaway of today,\" said Buffett on the video. His design, he said, \"lives beyond his lifetime and will live far beyond mine.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter earnings that showed that its cash pile swelled to $189 billion as of March 31 while the size of its stake in Apple fell. Based on changes in Apple's stock price, Berkshire appeared to have sold 13% of its Apple shares in the quarter.\n\nBuffett has long touted the iPhone maker's leadership and market dominance. Some investors have expressed concern that Apple had become too large a part of Berkshire's investment portfolio. Apple CEO Tim Cook was in the audience at the meeting on Saturday.\n\n\"The goal of Berkshire... is to increase the operating earnings,\" Buffett said as he kicked off the meeting with a run-down of the first quarter's earnings.\n\nIn downtown Omaha, hundreds of shareholders waited in line overnight to get in early. When the doors opened, some shareholders ran in to get good seats and the auditorium quickly filled up.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30 a.m.,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment portfolio manager who flew in with 40 others from Hong Kong and was standing first in line at one of the entrances. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAt a downtown arena, Buffett and Vice Chairman Greg Abel, 61, will answer about five hours of questions. Vice Chairman Ajit Jain, 72, will also join. Abel was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021.\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, brought a lawn chair to sit in while on line.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire. They're so diversified and have a good company culture. That's the one thing that I loved.\"\n\nInvestors are focused on how the conglomerate will evolve as it faces challenges including how best to grow without overpaying for acquisitions, whether to pay a dividend and how to deploy cash on hand that stood at $189 billion as of the end of March.\n\nSUCCESSION TOP OF MIND\n\nBerkshire is a $862 billion conglomerate with dozens of businesses including BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and Fruit of the Loom. It also owns well over $300 billion of stocks, close to half of which is Apple.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year, lagging the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain. Over the last decade, it has risen 218% versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBuffett is expected to face a wide array of questions on Saturday from major investments such as Apple and Occidental Petroleum to how elevated interest rates have affected the company.\n\n\"I want to see Warren's energy,\" said Steven Check, president of Check Capital Management, attending his 27th meeting. \"It's good that Greg and Ajit will be out front.\"\n\nBerkshire will also release first-quarter results and shareholders will vote on six proposals about climate, diversity and China. Buffett opposes all six.\n\nThe weekend features opportunities for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits featuring Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A 15-year shareholder, Gearhart said she was mainly concerned with what Buffett might say regarding his succession.\n\n\"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Track all of the day's news and analysis here.\n\nThe Berkshire Hathaway annual shareholders meeting Saturday will be broadcast exclusively on CNBC and livestreamed on CNBC.com. The special coverage will begin at 9:30 a.m. ET and all the day's events will be chronicled here.\n\nChairman and CEO Warren Buffett is expected to field questions from Berkshire Hathaway shareholders who are attending the meeting in Omaha, beginning at 10:15 a.m. ET.\n\nThe event is always closely watched, but this year's will be noteworthy because Buffett won't have Charlie Munger by his side. The investing legend died on Nov. 28, 2024, just weeks before what would have been his 100th birthday. Munger, the former vice chairman of Berkshire, was known for his sharp wit, and his absence is being felt by the thousands attending the event.\n\nAmong the questions that will be top of mind at the \"Woodstock for Capitalists\" will be what Buffett's mystery holding is. The firm was granted confidential treatment for an investment in past quarters, and it remains to be seen if that will continue or if Buffett will share more information at this weekend's gathering.\n\nCFRA is bullish on B shares of Berkshire Hathaway ahead of the company's annual meeting.\n\nThe firm called the stock \"undervalued versus historical averages\" and anticipates catalysts in the Berkshire Hathaway's earnings release Saturday morning.\n\nShares of Berkshire Hathaway are up nearly 13% year to date.\n\nTo read more about CFRA's call and what it expects from CEO Warren Buffett during the so-called \"Woodstock for Capitalists,\" read the full story here.\n\n-- Michelle Fox\n\nThere's a chance that Buffett will reveal the mystery wager Berkshire has been buying for two quarters straight.\n\nIn the third and fourth quarters of 2023, Berkshire was granted confidential treatment to keep the details of one or more of its stock holdings confidential.\n\nMany speculated that the secret purchase could be a bank stock as the conglomerate's cost basis for \"banks, insurance, and finance\" equity holdings jumped by $3.59 billion in the second half of last year, according to separate Berkshire filings.\n\nIt's relatively rare for Berkshire to request such a treatment. The last time it kept a purchase confidential was when it bought Chevron and Verizon in 2020.\n\n-- Yun Li\n\nThe annual meeting could start on a somber note with the absence of Charlie Munger on everyone's mind.\n\nPandemic lockdown apart, it will be the first without Munger, Buffett's longtime partner who passed away in November at the age of 99.\n\nFor the first time, Berkshire will broadcast its annual meeting movie that had previously always been reserved only for those in attendance in Omaha. Many speculate this year's will be a tear-jerker tribute to Munger.\n\nVice Chairman of Non-Insurance Operations Greg Abel, Buffett's designated successor, will fill Munger's seat in the afternoon session, helping answer shareholder questions.\n\nMunger left a mark on generations of investors in a host of ways thanks to a long and fruitful life. He broadened Buffett's investing approach to focus on quality companies selling at fair prices. Shareholders also appreciated Munger's one-of-a-kind bluntness and humor.\n\n-- Yun Li\n\nCNBC will be livestreaming Berkshire Hathaway's annual shareholder meeting on Saturday, beginning at 9:30 a.m. ET. Viewers can expect a lively discussion that will provide insight into Warren Buffett's view of the market, what types of deals Berkshire could make in the year ahead and other key topics.\n\nHere is a {"uri": "8110943417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "10:14:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T10:14:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T10:13:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.businesstelegraph.co.uk/warren-buffetts-shopping-extravaganza-kicks-off-with-squishmallows-pit-poor-charlies-almanack/", "title": "Warren Buffett's shopping extravaganza kicks off with Squishmallows pit, 'Poor Charlie's Almanack' - Business Telegraph", "body": "Squishmallows in the images of Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger display at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting at Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nOMAHA, Neb. -- Warren Buffett's annual shopping event, the pregame to Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting, is wowing shareholders flocking here this weekend.\n\nWith over 20,000 square feet of showroom space and more than 50,000 items of inventory, the exhibit hall at the CHI Health Center features goodies from various Berkshire's holding companies, from Brooks Running to See's Candies to Jazwares.\n\nOnly shareholders can participate at the event and they can buy items at a special discount.\n\nThe annual meeting will be exclusively broadcast on CNBC and livestreamed on CNBC.com. The special coverage will begin Saturday at 9:30 a.m. ET.\n\nJazwares\n\nSquishmallow pit at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nJazwares, the American toymaker best known for its Squishmallows plushie line, was a hit last year when it first displayed its wares at Berkshire Hathaway's conference, including the debut of a Warren Buffett plushie. This year, the company expanded its exhibit in the convention hall, making it three times larger.\n\nDisplays at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nSome highlights include the latest Squishmallows toys in the images of Buffett and his longtime Berkshire partner, Charlie Munger, a splashy Squishmallows pit, as well as other displays.\n\n'Poor Charlie's Almanack'\n\nCharles Munger remembrance ahead of the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting at Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nThe Bookworm only had one book to sell this year: \"Poor Charlie's Almanack: The Essential Wit and Wisdom of Charles T. Munger.\" That was at the request of Buffett in honor of his business partner of more than 60 years, who passed away in November at the age of 99.\n\nFlightSafety\n\nFlightSafety at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nBerkshire acquired pilot training company FlightSafety in 1996. At Friday's shopping event, the firm brought a taste of what its training program looks like for professional pilots. Shareholders lined up to put on virtual reality glasses and experience the flight simulation training.\n\nPilot Travel Centers\n\nPilot Travel display ahead of the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting at Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nTruck-stop giant Pilot Travel Centers put up a big display with a real-sized red truck. The firm is largest operator of travel centers in North America, with more than 750 locations. Berkshire now fully owns Pilot Travel after buying the remaining 20% ownership interest from the Haslam family. The deal was not without drama as the Haslams last year sued Berkshire in a complaint that accused the conglomerate of using so-called pushdown accounting without authorization from the family.\n\nDuracell\n\nDuracell display at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nIn 2016, Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway bought Duracell from Procter & Gamble, offering the consumer giant $4.7 billion of the shares it owned in P&G in exchange for the battery maker.\n\nBrooks Running\n\nDisplays at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nBrooks Running attracted a long line of shareholders snapping up the 2024 special edition of its running shoes with \"brk\" on the side and a cartoon of a running Buffett on the insoles. Many shareholders are also set to participate in the Brooks \"Invest in Yourself\" 5K fun run and walk on Sunday, the morning following the annual meeting.\n\nDairy Queen\n\nDairy Queen display at the Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, on May 3, 2024.\n\nSarah Min | CNBC\n\nWarren Buffett bought Dairy Queen in 1998 in a roughly $600 million transaction, and has made trips to the Omaha locations with his great-grandchildren. According to The Wall Street Journal, the billionaire investor has said in the past that his favorite DQ order is a vanilla soft serve topped with chocolate syrup and malted milk power.\n\nCorrection: Berkshire Hathaway's annual shareholder meeting is held in Nebraska. Captions in an earlier version didn't cite that state.\n\nDon't miss these exclusives from CNBC PRO\n\nREAD SOURCE", "source": {"uri": "businesstelegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Business {"uri": "8111367401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "17:03:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T17:03:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T17:03:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/at-berkshire-shareholder-meeting,-buffett-exhorts-successors,-pays-tribute-to-munger/76903413", "title": "At Berkshire shareholder meeting, Buffett exhorts successors, pays tribute to Munger", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) -Warren Buffett took the stage at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, paying tribute to his longtime business partner Charlie Munger while outlining the expanded roles of the executives who are designated to eventually succeed him in leading the company.\n\nThe meeting is the 60th for Buffett, 93, since he took over Berkshire in 1965. He has largely stopped appearing publicly to discuss the company. He told investors in November that he felt good but knew he was \"playing in extra innings.\"\n\nBuffett said he was comfortable letting chief executives of Berkshire's operating units deal directly with Vice Chairman Greg Abel and Vice Chairman Ajit Jain. Abel, 61, designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021, sat on stage with Buffett.\n\n\"When you've got somebody like Greg and Ajit, why settle for me?\" he said. \"It has worked out extremely well.\"\n\nThe shareholder meeting is the first since Charlie Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99.\n\n\"I have been in the position of having people I trust around me,\" said Buffett on stage, who then referenced Munger. Earlier, in a video ahead of the meeting, Berkshire played a tribute to Munger showing photos of Omaha from 1924 and footage of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\n\"Charlie's architectural thoughts led to the Berkshire Hathaway of today,\" said Buffett on the video. His design, he said, \"lives beyond his lifetime and will live far beyond mine.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter earnings that showed that its cash pile swelled to $189 billion as of March 31 while the size of its stake in Apple fell. Based on changes in Apple's stock price, Berkshire appeared to have sold 13% of its Apple shares in the quarter.\n\nBuffett has long touted the iPhone maker's leadership and market dominance. Some investors have expressed concern that Apple had become too large a part of Berkshire's investment portfolio. Apple CEO Tim Cook was in the audience at the meeting on Saturday.\n\nStill, Buffett assured shareholders that \"unless something dramatic happens that really changes capital allocation, we will have Apple as our largest investment.\"\n\nBuffett also said he didn't mind expanding the company's cash stake, with comparatively few alternatives in the equity markets and conflicts around the world, and said cash could top $200 billion by the end of June.\n\nHe added that Berkshire remains committed to the U.S.\n\n\"We will be American oriented,\" Buffett said. \"If we do something really big it's extremely likely it will be in the United States.\"\n\nBuffett assured shareholders that \"unless something dramatic happens\" that really changes Berkshire's capital allocation, it will have Apple as its largest investment.\n\nAbel addressed issues at Berkshire's energy business, saying Berkshire will fight litigation related to wildfires but that it was a substantial challenge. The unit faces billions of dollars in claims against its PacifiCorp unit over Oregon wildfires in 2020.\n\nIn downtown Omaha, hundreds of shareholders waited in line overnight to get in early. When the doors opened, some shareholders ran in to get good seats and the auditorium quickly filled up.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30 a.m.,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment portfolio manager who flew in with 40 others from Hong Kong and was standing first in line at one of the entrances. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, brought a lawn chair to sit in while on line.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire. They're so diversified and have a good company culture. That's the one thing that I loved.\"\n\nInvestors are focused on how the conglomerate will evolve as it faces challenges including how best to grow without overpaying for acquisitions, whether to pay a dividend and how to deploy cash on hand that stood at $189 billion as of the end of March.\n\nSUCCESSION TOP OF MIND Berkshire is a $862 billion conglomerate with dozens of businesses including BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and Fruit of the Loom. It also owns well over $300 billion of stocks, close to half of which is Apple.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year, lagging the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain. Over the last decade, it has risen 218% versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBuffett is expected to face a wide array of questions on Saturday from major investments such as Apple and Occidental Petroleum to how elevated interest rates have affected the company. Berkshire will also release first-quarter results and shareholders will vote on six proposals about climate, diversity and China. Buffett opposes all six. The weekend features opportunities for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits featuring Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A 15-year shareholder, Gearhart said she was mainly concerned with what Buffett might say regarding his succession. \"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345009392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "14:46:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T14:46:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T13:58:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/profit-drops-at-warren-buffetts-firm-but-thousands-still-want-to-hear-from-the-investing/article_b12c5c2e-379d-5d9c-ba42-ac8521df1fbe.html", "title": "Profit drops at Warren Buffett's firm but thousands still want to hear from the investing guru", "body": "Warren Buffett's company reported a steep drop in earnings Saturday because the paper value of its investments fell, but the tens of thousands of shareholders filling an Omaha arena to hear Buffett answer questions at the annual meeting later can take heart that Berkshire Hathaway's many businesses performed well\n\nOMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- Warren Buffett's company reported a steep drop in earnings Saturday because the paper value of its investments fell, but the tens of thousands of shareholders filling an Omaha arena to hear Buffett answer questions at the annual meeting later can take heart that Berkshire Hathaway's many businesses performed well.\n\nBerkshire reported a $12.7 billion profit, or $8.825 per Class A share, in the quarter. That's roughly one-third of the $35.5 billion, or $24,377 per A share, that Berkshire reported a year ago.\n\nBut those figures were heavily swayed by a large drop in the paper value of Berkshire's investments. That's why Buffett encourages investors to pay more attention to the conglomerate's operating earnings that exclude the investment figures. By that measure, Berkshire's operating earnings jumped 39% to $11.222 billion from last year's $8.065 billion as its insurance companies led a strong performance.\n\nThe three analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had predicted operating earnings of $6,701.87 per Class A share.\n\nBuffett did sell off nearly $6 billion in stocks during the quarter, including trimming about 13% of Berkshire's massive Apple stake. The investment in the iPhone maker is still the biggest one in the $364 billion portfolio at $135.4 billion.\n\nBut the estimated value of Berkshire's Apple stake suggests that Buffett sold off more than 100 million shares. Buffett has said he invested in Apple's stock because of how devoted consumers are to the iPhone and other Apple products.\n\nApple CEO Tim Cook, who is at the Berkshire meeting, told CNBC that he still considers it a privilege to have Berkshire as a major shareholder.\n\nBerkshire reported a $2.6 billion underwriting profit at its insurers, up from $911 million a year ago.\n\nBNSF railroad's profits did disappoint and drop 8% to $1.143 billion, but most of its many other companies delivered solid results, including a 72% jump in operating profits at the utility unit that added $717 million to Berkshire's total.\n\nBerkshire's revenue grew 5% to $89.87 billion in the quarter. The two analysts who reported estimates to FactSet predicted $87.044 billion revenue.\n\nWith no major acquisitions in sight, Berkshire's massive cash pile continued to grow to a record $188.993 billion in the quarter. Berkshire even spent $2.6 billion repurchasing shares during the first three months of the year, but its companies that include Geico insurance, BNSF railroad, several major utilities and an assortment of dozens of others keep generating mountains of cash.\n\nTHOUSANDS ATTEND WARREN BUFFETT'S 'WOODSTOCK FOR CAPITALISTS'\n\nThe main arena was already three-quarters full within half an hour of the doors opening Saturday because people are always eager to vacuum up tidbits of wisdom from billionaire Warren Buffett, who famously dubbed the meeting 'Woodstock for Capitalists.'\n\nBut a key ingredient is missing this year: It's the first meeting since Vice Chairman Charlie Munger died.\n\nThe meeting opened with a video tribute to Munger recounting his life and highlighting some of his best known quotes from the meetings over the years, including classic lines like \"If people weren't so often wrong, we wouldn't be so rich.\" The video also featured old interviews with Buffett and Munger talking about their epic friendship.\n\nFor decades, Munger shared the stage with Buffett every year for the marathon question and answer session that is the event's centerpiece. Munger routinely let Buffett take the lead with expansive responses that went on for several minutes. Then Munger himself would cut directly to the point. He is remembered for calling cryptocurrencies stupid, telling people to \"marry the best person that will have you\" and comparing many unproven internet businesses in 2000 to \"turds.\"\n\nHe and Buffett functioned as a classic comedy duo, with Buffett offering lengthy setups to Munger's witty one-liners. Together, they transformed Berkshire from a floundering textile mill into a massive conglomerate made up of a variety of interests, from insurance companies such as Geico to BNSF railroad to several major utilities and an assortment of other companies.\n\nMunger often summed up the key Berkshire's success as \"trying to be consistently not stupid, instead of trying to be very intelligent.\" He and Buffett also were known for sticking to businesses they understood well.\n\n\"Warren always did at least 80% of the talking. But Charlie was a great foil,\" said Stansberry Research analyst Whitney Tilson, who was looking forward to his 27th consecutive meeting with a bit of a heavy heart because of Munger's absence.\n\nThat absence, however, may well create space for shareholders to get to know better the two executives who directly oversee Berkshire's companies: Ajit Jain, who manages the insurance units, and Greg Abel, who handles everything else. Abel will one day replace the 93-year-old Buffett as CEO.\n\nMorningstar analyst Greggory Warren said he hopes Abel will speak up more this year and let shareholders see some of the brilliance Berkshire executives talk about. Ever since Munger let it slip at the annual meeting three years ago that Abel would be the successor, Buffett has repeatedly reassured investors that he's confident in the pick.\n\nExperts say the company has a solid culture built on integrity, trust, independence and an impressive management roster ready to take over.\n\n\"Greg's a rock star,\" said Chris Bloomstran, president of Semper Augustus Investments Group. \"The bench is deep. He won't have the same humor at the meeting. But I think we all come here to get a reminder every year to be rational.\"\n\n___\n\nFor more AP coverage of Warren Buffett look here: https://apnews.com/hub/warren-buffett. For Berkshire Hathaway news, see here: https://apnews.com/hub/berkshire-hathaway-inc. CaptainU as Official College Recruiting Software System4 Continues Growth, Opens First Office in Hawaii Striking deals to end campus protests, some colleges invite discussion of their investments", {"uri": "8111282982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "15:39:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T15:39:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T15:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/berkshire-shareholders-descend-omaha-annual-100508871.html", "title": "Buffett takes stage at Berkshire meeting, pays tribute to Munger, cuts Apple stake", "body": "OMAHA, Nebraska (Reuters) - Warren Buffett took the stage at Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting on Saturday, paying tribute to his longtime business partner Charlie Munger who died last year and outlining Berkshire's goal to grow earnings.\n\nThe meeting is the 60th for Buffett, 93, since he took over Berkshire in 1965. He has largely stopped appearing publicly to discuss the company. He told investors in November that he felt good but knew he was \"playing in extra innings.\"\n\nThe shareholder meeting is the first since Charlie Munger, Buffett's longtime friend, business partner and foil, died in November at age 99. In a video ahead of the meeting, Berkshire played a tribute to Charlie Munger showing photos of Omaha from 1924 and footage of Buffett and Munger through the years.\n\nMunger was known for laconic and acerbic comebacks to Buffett's often lengthy appraisals about Berkshire, the economy, Wall Street and life.\n\n\"Charlie's architectural thoughts led to the Berkshire Hathaway of today,\" said Buffett on the video. His design, he said, \"lives beyond his lifetime and will live far beyond mine.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Berkshire reported first-quarter earnings that showed that its cash pile swelled to $189 billion as of March 31 while the size of its stake in Apple fell. Based on changes in Apple's stock price, Berkshire appeared to have sold 13% of its Apple shares in the quarter.\n\nBuffett has long touted the iPhone maker's leadership and market dominance. Some investors have expressed concern that Apple had become too large a part of Berkshire's investment portfolio. Apple CEO Tim Cook was in the audience at the meeting on Saturday.\n\n\"The goal of Berkshire... is to increase the operating earnings,\" Buffett said as he kicked off the meeting with a run-down of the first quarter's earnings.\n\nIn downtown Omaha, hundreds of shareholders waited in line overnight to get in early. When the doors opened, some shareholders ran in to get good seats and the auditorium quickly filled up.\n\n\"I was here since 2:30 a.m.,\" said Serena Lam, 32, an investment portfolio manager who flew in with 40 others from Hong Kong and was standing first in line at one of the entrances. \"I want to see Warren Buffett. I want to get his perspective about Japanese stocks. I flew over 25 hours for this.\"\n\nAt a downtown arena, Buffett and Vice Chairman Greg Abel, 61, will answer about five hours of questions. Vice Chairman Ajit Jain, 72, will also join. Abel was designated Buffett's successor as chief executive in 2021.\n\nBill Gunther, 72, a retired state forester from Newfane, Vermont, brought a lawn chair to sit in while on line.\n\n\"I feel very bullish about Berkshire. They're so diversified and have a good company culture. That's the one thing that I loved.\"\n\nInvestors are focused on how the conglomerate will evolve as it faces challenges including how best to grow without overpaying for acquisitions, whether to pay a dividend and how to deploy cash on hand that stood at $189 billion as of the end of March.\n\nSUCCESSION TOP OF MIND\n\nBerkshire is a $862 billion conglomerate with dozens of businesses including BNSF railroad, Geico car insurance, Dairy Queen and Fruit of the Loom. It also owns well over $300 billion of stocks, close to half of which is Apple.\n\nBerkshire's stock is up 23% over the last year, lagging the Standard & Poor's 500's 25% gain. Over the last decade, it has risen 218% versus the S&P's 172% gain.\n\nBuffett is expected to face a wide array of questions on Saturday from major investments such as Apple and Occidental Petroleum to how elevated interest rates have affected the company. \"I want to see Warren's energy,\" said Steven Check, president of Check Capital Management, attending his 27th meeting. \"It's good that Greg and Ajit will be out front.\" Berkshire will also release first-quarter results and shareholders will vote on six proposals about climate, diversity and China. Buffett opposes all six. The weekend features opportunities for shareholders to buy goodies such as Berkshire T-shirts and Squishmallows toys at exhibits featuring Berkshire-owned companies.\n\nRuth Gearhart, 72, from Omaha, filled her bags with See's Candies plus tongs and spatulas from Pampered Chef. A 15-year shareholder, Gearhart said she was mainly concerned with what Buffett might say regarding his succession. \"I trust him,\" she said. \"He's a brilliant man and he has a lot of brilliant people. He will get us through this. I'd hate to see him go, but I think they prepared for it well.\"\n\n(Reporting by Gui Qing Koh and Jonathan Stempel; additional reporting by Scott Morgan and Davide Barbuscia; editing by Ira Iosebashvili, Megan Davies, Cynthia Osterman, Jason Neely and Diane Craft)", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Munger", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Charlie Munger"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Berkshire Hathaway"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_Buffett", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Warren Buffett"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8111373783", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "17:10:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T17:10:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T17:09:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-first-annual-meeting-since-charlie-munger-death/", "title": "Berkshire Hathaway has first annual meeting since death of longtime vice chairman Charlie Munger", "body": "Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway gathered for its first annual meeting in an Omaha arena on Saturday, bringing together shareholders for the first time since the death of longtime vice chairman and right-hand man Charlie Munger.\n\nTens of thousands of shareholders filled the arena eager to vacuum up tidbits of wisdom from billionaire Buffett, who famously dubbed the meeting \"Woodstock for Capitalists\" and to pay tribute to Munger, who died at 99 in November.\n\nThe meeting opened with a video tribute to Munger recounting his life and highlighting some of his best known quotes from the meetings over the years that drew applause, including classic lines like \"If people weren't so often wrong, we wouldn't be so rich.\" The video also featured old interviews with Buffett and Munger talking about their epic friendship.\n\nThe video also featured several of the classic skits the investors made for meetings over the years with holiday stars like a \"Desperate Housewives\" spoof where one of the women introduced Munger as her boyfriend and another video where Jamie Lee Curtis swooned over Munger.\n\nAs the video ended, everyone in the arena gave Munger a prolonged standing ovation to thank him for being what Buffett called \"the architect of Berkshire Hathaway.\"\n\nFor decades, Munger shared the stage with Buffett every year for the marathon question and answer session that is the event's centerpiece. Munger routinely let Buffett take the lead with expansive responses that went on for several minutes. Then Munger himself would cut directly to the point. He is remembered for calling cryptocurrencies stupid, telling people to \"marry the best person that will have you\" and comparing many unproven internet businesses in 2000 to \"turds.\"\n\nHe and Buffett functioned as a classic comedy duo, with Buffett offering lengthy setups to Munger's witty one-liners. Together, they transformed Berkshire from a floundering textile mill into a massive conglomerate made up of a variety of interests, from insurance companies such as Geico to BNSF railroad to several major utilities and an assortment of other companies.\n\nMunger often summed up the key Berkshire's success as \"trying to be consistently not stupid, instead of trying to be very intelligent.\" He and Buffett also were known for sticking to businesses they understood well.\n\n\"Warren always did at least 80% of the talking. But Charlie was a great foil,\" said Stansberry Research analyst Whitney Tilson, who was looking forward to his 27th consecutive meeting with a bit of a heavy heart because of Munger's absence.\n\nThat absence, however, may well create space for shareholders to get to know better the two executives who directly oversee Berkshire's companies: Ajit Jain, who manages the insurance units, and Greg Abel, who handles everything else. Abel will one day replace the 93-year-old Buffett as CEO. Abel and Jain are sharing the main stage with Buffett for the first time this year in the spot Munger used to occupy.\n\nThe first time Buffett kicked a question to Abel, he mistakenly said \"Charlie?\" out of habit.\n\nMorningstar analyst Greggory Warren said he hopes Abel will speak up more this year and let shareholders see some of the brilliance Berkshire executives talk about. Ever since Munger let it slip at the annual meeting three years ago that Abel would be the successor, Buffett has repeatedly reassured investors that he's confident in the pick.\n\nBuffett's company reported a steep drop in earnings because the paper value of its investments fell and it sold off part of its massive Apple stake, but overall, Berkshire Hathaway's many businesses performed well.\n\nBerkshire reported a $12.7 billion profit, or $8,825 per Class A share, in the quarter. That's roughly one-third of the $35.5 billion, or $24,377 per A share, that Berkshire reported a year ago.\n\nBut those figures were heavily swayed by a large drop in the paper value of Berkshire's investments. That's why Buffett encourages investors to pay more attention to the conglomerate's operating earnings that exclude the investment figures. By that measure, Berkshire's operating earnings jumped 39% to $11.222 billion from last year's $8.065 billion as its insurance companies led a strong performance.\n\nThe three analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had predicted operating earnings of $6,701.87 per Class A share.\n\nBuffett did sell off nearly $6 billion in stocks during the quarter, including trimming about 13% of Berkshire's massive Apple stake. The investment in the iPhone maker is still the biggest one in the $364 billion portfolio at $135.4 billion, and Buffett said he expects Apple to remain the biggest investment for years -- even up to when his successor takes over.\n\nBut the estimated value of Berkshire's Apple stake suggests that Buffett sold off more than 100 million shares. Buffett has said he invested in Apple's stock because of how devoted consumers are to the iPhone and other Apple products.\n\nApple CEO Tim Cook, who is at the Berkshire meeting, told CNBC that he still considers it a privilege to have Berkshire as a major shareholder, and he knew about the sales before Berkshire disclosed them Saturday.\n\nBerkshire reported a $2.6 billion underwriting profit at its insurers, up from $911 million a year ago.\n\nBNSF railroad's profits did disappoint and drop 8% to $1.143 billion, but most of its many other companies delivered solid results, including a 72% jump in operating profits at the utility unit that added $717 million to Berkshire's total.\n\nBerkshire's revenue grew 5% to $89.87 billion in the quarter. The two analysts who reported estimates to FactSet predicted $87.044 billion revenue.\n\nWith no major acquisitions in sight, Berkshire's massive cash pile continued to grow to a record $188.993 billion in the quarter. Berkshire even spent $2.6 billion repurchasing shares during the first three months of the year, but its companies include Geico insurance, BNSF railroad, several major utilities and an assortment of dozens of others keep generating mountains of cash.\n\n\"We'd love to spend it but we won't spend it unless we're doing something with very little risk that will make us a lot of money,\" Buffett said.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Munger", "type": "person", "score": 5,
